description: From Middle English purporten, from Anglo-Norman purporter and Old French porporter (“convey, contain, carry”), from pur-, from Latin pro (“forth”) + Old French porter (“carry”), from Latin portō (“carry”).

examples: A child’s brain starts functioning at birth; and has, amongst its many infant convolutions, thousands of dormant atoms, into which God has put a mystic possibility for noticing an adult’s act, and figuring out its purport.

verbs.description: purport (third-person singular simple present purports, present participle purporting, simple past and past participle purported)

entries.meaning: To convey, imply, or profess (often falsely or inaccurately).
examples: He purports himself to be an international man of affairs.
He purported to become an international man of affairs.
